Lesson 1: Great Start to Quality Overview

Great Start to Quality (GSQ) is Michigan’s quality recognition and improvement system for licensed child care providers that want to have their programs evaluated and take steps to improve their quality. It is funded by the Department of Michigan Lifelong Education, Advancement, and Potential (MiLEAP) and includes 10 Resource Centers  across the state that provide a comprehensive evaluation plan for programs serving children birth through school age. Great Start to Quality also shares information about programs with families and helps them select the right program for their needs.

GSQ Resource Centers

Some of the additional supports GSQ provides for child care providers and families through the ten Resource Centers include:

  • Professional development and training opportunities, including in-person, and virtual.
  • A free Lending Library that offers themed kits, curriculum, administrative books, books on child development, DVDs, books, CDs, gross motor items, and more.
  • Support from a Quality Improvement Specialist (QIS) to help programs navigate Great Start to Quality.
  • Support to families searching for child care and preschool that best meets their needs.
  • Free on-site, individual coaching from a Quality Improvement Coach (QIC) to support home and center-based early learning programs in providing high quality care to children and families.

Getting Started with The Quality Improvement Process

If a program chooses to participate in Quality Improvement through GSQ, the process is fully supported along the way. Programs will have multiple opportunities to engage in reflection and self-assessment on their own using a variety of tools provided by GSQ. Later in the process, programs will benefit from trained Assessors observing and providing feedback and data.

Instructions: Select each dropdown below to learn about the steps in the Quality Improvement Process

  1. Step 1

    • Submit Application

      Process

      For licensed child care programs to participate in Great Start to Quality and receive a Quality Level, each program must have an Organization Profile, and qualification information for each educator (staff member) must be in MiRegistry. The application can be found in the Quality Improvement tab of the program’s Organization Profile in MiRegistry. The MiRegistry-Great Start to Quality(PDF) includes additional information on getting started.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Basic step to create a Self-Reflection specific to the program type and offerings.

  2. Step 2

    • Submit Self-Reflection

      Process

      GSQ uses 40 indicators to measure the overall quality that programs provide across five categories in the Self-Reflection. These indicators are aligned with Michigan’s Early Childhood Standards of Quality (ECSQ) and the National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC). Great Start to Quality has additional information on their Reflecting on Quality webpage.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Allows a comprehensive overview of quality and an opportunity to self-identify strengths and growth areas for the program.

  3. Step 3

    • Create and Meet Goals

      Process

      Quality Improvement Coaches (QICs) meet with programs to make and carry out plans for quality improvement.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Collaborative and supportive partnership with trained experts provides a strong goal-setting process and resources to succeed at them and make improvements aligned with the needs of the children and families they serve.

  4. Step 4

    • Submit Application for Validation and On-Site Observation

      Process

      Programs complete an application for Validation and On-Site Observation, indicating they are ready to have their Self-Reflection reviewed and move through the next steps in the process.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Programs indicate they have made improvements and are ready to move to the Validation and On-Site Observation process to gain additional feedback to improve their program.

  5. Step 5

    • Submit Self-Reflection

      Process

      Programs update their Self-Reflection to align with improvements they have made or goals achieved.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Allows program to communicate their progress towards quality improvements and self-identify strengths and growth areas for the program.

  6. Step 6

    • Review by Quality Improvement Coach

      Process

      QICs review goals to discuss completion and outcomes with the program. They also review the Self-Reflection to ensure completion and discuss the observation tools the program can choose or their On-Site Observation.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      This step provides a check and balance to ensure goals are completed and the program is ready for the next steps in the process.

  7. Step 7

    • Validation

      Process

      Validation is the process by which members of the Validation Team at the Early Childhood Investment Corporation review a program’s Self-Reflection responses and corresponding evidence to verify the program’s high quality practices. The results of the Validation are shared publicly so families can review the strengths of each program during their search for child care.

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      Objective review of policies and practices means more ideas and feedback for ways to grow.

  8. Step 8

    • On-Site Observation

      Process

      A Great Start to Quality, or approved external Assessor, comes unannounced during a scheduled window of time and uses three reliable and valid tools to observe program practices. This provides objective results that highlight strengths in program quality and gives a clear picture of areas in which to improve. These three tools are:

      • Classroom Assessment Scoring System (CLASS)
      • Environment Rating Scales (ERS)
      • Social & Emotional Learning Program Quality Assessment (SEL PQA).

      Purpose As It Relates To Quality Improvement

      The cycle of reflection, goal-setting, data-gathering, observations, and collaboration continues indefinitely. There is always room to improve and participating in GSQ shows the program’s commitment to providing a high quality program to the children and families in their community.

Levels of Quality in GSQ's Quality Improvement

Image by Matt Duncan under Unsplash

GSQ believes Quality Improvement is a continuous process — a journey without end. There is always new research and learnings in the field of Early Care and Education and in the new process, programs are encouraged and supported to continue to reflect on their practices, in line with the program’s mission. This can assist programs in creating goals that ensure the best quality care for the children and families they serve.

There are now levels of Quality. All published quality levels are valid for 2 years and results will be posted for families on the program’s public profile where families search for care. Select each level for more detailed information on the Great Start to Quality website.

Instructions: Select each “+” below to learn more about the different levels of quality.

Additional Resources

Detailed information about each GSQ quality level can be found on the following webpages for each level:

  • Maintaining Health and Safety
  • Reflecting on Quality
  • Enhancing Quality
  • Enhancing Quality – Validated
  • Demonstrating Quality
